title: Lhasa
text:
Lhasa (; Lhasa dialect: ; ) is the urban center of the <a href="prefecture-level%20city">prefecture-level</a> <a href="Lhasa%20%28prefecture-level%20city%29">Lhasa City</a> and the administrative capital of <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a>. The inner urban area of Lhasa City is equivalent to the administrative borders of Chengguan District (), which is part of the wider prefectural Lhasa City.
Lhasa is the second most populous urban area on the <a href="Tibetan%20Plateau">Tibetan Plateau</a> after <a href="Xining">Xining</a> and, at an altitude of , Lhasa is one of the <a href="highest%20cities%20in%20the%20world">highest cities in the world</a>. The city has been the religious and administrative capital of <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a> since the mid-17th century. It contains many culturally significant <a href="Tibetan%20Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhist</a> sites such as the <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a>, <a href="Jokhang">Jokhang</a> Temple and <a href="Norbulingka">Norbulingka</a> Palaces.
Toponymy.
Lhasa literally translates to "place of gods" ( , god; , place) in the <a href="Standard%20Tibetan">Tibetan language</a>. Chengguan literally translates to "urban gateway" () in the Chinese language. Ancient Tibetan documents and inscriptions demonstrate that the place was called Rasa (), which meant “goat’s place,” as it was a herding site.. The name was changed to Lhasa, which means “place of gods” upon its establishment as the capital of Tibet, and construction of the Jokhang temple was completed, which housed a holy statue of the Buddha. Lhasa is first recorded as the name, referring to the area's temple of Jowo, in a treaty drawn up between China and Tibet in 822 C.E.
History.
By the mid 7th century, <a href="Songtsen%20Gampo">Songtsen Gampo</a> became the leader of the <a href="Tibetan%20Empire">Tibetan Empire</a> that had risen to power in the <a href="Brahmaputra%20River">Brahmaputra River</a> (locally known as the "<a href="Yarlung%20Tsangpo%20River">Yarlung Tsangpo River</a>") Valley. After conquering the kingdom of <a href="Zhangzhung">Zhangzhung</a> in the west, he moved the capital from the Chingwa <a href="Takts%C3%A9%20Castle">Taktsé Castle</a> in <a href="Chongye%20County">Chongye County</a> (<a href="pinyin">pinyin</a>: Qióngjié Xiàn), southwest of <a href="Yarlung%20Valley">Yarlung</a>, to Rasa (Lhasa) where in 637 he raised the first structures on the site of what is now the <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a> on Mount Marpori.
In CE 639 and 641, Songtsen Gampo, who by this time had conquered the whole Tibetan region, is said to have contracted two alliance marriages, firstly to a Princess <a href="Bhrikuti">Bhrikuti</a> of Nepal, and then, two years later, to <a href="Princess%20Wencheng">Princess Wencheng</a> of the Imperial <a href="Tang%20dynasty">Tang</a> court. Bhrikuti is said to have converted him to <a href="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, which was also the faith attributed to his second wife Wencheng. In 641 he constructed the <a href="Jokhang">Jokhang</a> (or Rasa Trülnang Tsulagkhang) and <a href="Ramoche%20Temple">Ramoche Temple</a>s in Lhasa in order to house two <a href="Buddha%20statue">Buddha statue</a>s, the <a href="Akshobhya">Akshobhya Vajra</a> (depicting the Buddha at the age of eight) and the <a href="Jowo%20%28statue%29">Jowo Sakyamuni</a> (depicting Buddha at the age of twelve), respectively brought to his court by the princesses. Lhasa suffered extensive damage under the reign of <a href="Langdarma">Langdarma</a> in the 9th century, when the sacred sites were destroyed and desecrated and the empire fragmented.
A Tibetan tradition mentions that after Songtsen Gampo's death in 649 C.E., Chinese troops captured Lhasa and burnt the Red Palace. Chinese and Tibetan scholars have noted that the event is mentioned neither in the Chinese annals nor in the Tibetan manuscripts of <a href="Dunhuang">Dunhuang</a>. Lǐ suggested that this tradition may derive from an <a href="Interpolation%20%28manuscripts%29">interpolation</a>. <a href="Tsepon%20W.%20D.%20Shakabpa">Tsepon W. D. Shakabpa</a> believes that "those histories reporting the arrival of Chinese troops are not correct."
From the fall of the monarchy in the 9th century to the accession of the <a href="5th%20Dalai%20Lama">5th Dalai Lama</a>, the centre of political power in the Tibetan region was not situated in Lhasa. However, the importance of Lhasa as a religious site became increasingly significant as the centuries progressed. It was known as the centre of Tibet where <a href="Padmasambhava">Padmasambhava</a> magically pinned down the earth demoness and built the foundation of the <a href="Jokhang%20Temple">Jokhang Temple</a> over her heart. Islam has been present since the 11th century in what is considered to have always been a monolithically Buddhist culture. Two <a href="Tibetan%20Muslim">Tibetan Muslim</a> communities have lived in Lhasa with distinct homes, food and clothing, language, education, trade and traditional herbal medicine.
By the 15th century, the city of Lhasa had risen to prominence following the founding of three large <a href="Gelugpa">Gelugpa</a> monasteries by <a href="Je%20Tsongkhapa">Je Tsongkhapa</a> and his disciples. The three monasteries are <a href="Ganden">Ganden</a>, <a href="Sera%20monastery">Sera</a> and <a href="Drepung">Drepung</a> which were built as part of the puritanical Buddhist revival in Tibet. The scholarly achievements and political know-how of this Gelugpa Lineage eventually pushed Lhasa once more to centre stage.
The 5th <a href="Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a>, <a href="Lobsang%20Gyatso">Lobsang Gyatso</a> (1617–1682), unified Tibet and moved the centre of his administration to Lhasa in 1642 with the help of <a href="G%C3%BCshi%20Khan">Güshi Khan</a> of the <a href="Khoshut">Khoshut</a>. With Güshi Khan as a largely uninvolved overlord, the 5th Dalai Lama and his intimates established a civil administration which is referred to by historians as the "Lhasa state". The core leadership of this government is also referred to as the <a href="Ganden%20Phodrang">Ganden Phodrang</a>, and Lhasa thereafter became both the religious and political capital. In 1645, the reconstruction of the <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a> began on Red Hill. In 1648, the "Potrang Karpo" (<a href="Potala%23White%20Palace">White Palace</a>) of the Potala was completed, and the Potala was used as a <a href="winter%20palace">winter palace</a> by the Dalai Lama from that time onwards. The "Potrang Marpo" (<a href="Potala%23Red%20Palace">Red Palace</a>) was added between 1690 and 1694. The name Potala is derived from <a href="Mount%20Potalaka">Mount Potalaka</a>, the mythical abode of the Dalai Lama's divine prototype, the <a href="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a> <a href="Avalokite%C5%9Bvara">Avalokiteśvara</a>. The Jokhang Temple was also greatly expanded around this time. Although some wooden carvings and <a href="lintel%20%28architecture%29">lintel</a>s of the Jokhang Temple date to the 7th century, the oldest of Lhasa's extant buildings, such as within the Potala Palace, the Jokhang and some of the monasteries and properties in the Old Quarter date to this second flowering in Lhasa's history.
By the end of the 17th century, Lhasa's <a href="Barkhor">Barkhor</a> area formed a bustling market for foreign goods. The Jesuit missionary, <a href="Ippolito%20Desideri">Ippolito Desideri</a> reported in 1716 that the city had a cosmopolitan community of Mongol, Chinese, Muscovite, Armenian, Kashmiri, Nepalese and Northern Indian traders. Tibet was exporting musk, gold, medicinal plants, furs and yak tails to far-flung markets, in exchange for sugar, tea, saffron, Persian turquoise, European amber and Mediterranean coral. The <a href="Qing%20dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> army entered Lhasa in 1720, and the Qing government sent resident commissioners, called the <a href="Amban">Amban</a>s, to Lhasa. In November 11 of 1750, the murder of the regent by the Ambans triggered a <a href="Lhasa%20riot%20of%201750">riot in the city</a> that left more than a hundred people killed, including the Ambans. After suppressing the rebels, Qing <a href="Qianlong%20Emperor">Qianlong Emperor</a> reorganized the Tibetan government and set up the governing council called <a href="Kashag">Kashag</a> in Lhasa in 1751. 
In January 1904, a <a href="British%20Empire">British</a> <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">expeditionary force</a> invaded and captured Lhasa during the <a href="British%20expedition%20to%20Tibet">British expedition to Tibet</a>. The expedition's leader, <a href="Francis%20Younghusband">Sir Francis Younghusband</a> negotiated the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lhasa">Convention Between Great Britain and Tibet</a> with the remaining Tibetan officials after the <a href="13th%20Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a> had fled to the countryside. The treaty was subsequently repudiated and was succeeded by <a href="Convention%20Between%20Great%20Britain%20and%20China%20Respecting%20Tibet">a 1906 Anglo-Chinese treaty</a>. All Qing troops left Lhasa after the <a href="Xinhai%20Lhasa%20turmoil">Xinhai Lhasa turmoil</a> in 1912.
By the 20th century, Lhasa, long a beacon for both Tibetan and foreign Buddhists, had numerous ethnically and religiously distinct communities, among them <a href="Tibetan%20Muslims">Kashmiri Muslims</a>, <a href="Ladakh">Ladakh</a>i merchants, <a href="Islam%20and%20Sikhism">Sikh converts to Islam</a>, and Chinese traders and officials. The Kashmiri Muslims ("Khache") trace their arrival in Lhasa to the Muslim saint of <a href="Patna">Patna</a>, Khair ud-Din, contemporary with the 5th Dalai Lama. <a href="Islam%20in%20China">Chinese Muslims</a> lived in a quarter to the south, and <a href="Lhasa%20Newar%20%28trans-Himalayan%20traders%29">Newar merchants</a> from <a href="Kathmandu">Kathmandu</a> to the north of the Barkhor market. Residents of the Lubu neighbourhood were descended from Chinese vegetable farmers who stayed over after accompanying an <a href="Amban">Amban</a> from <a href="Sichuan">Sichuan</a> in the mid-nineteenth century; some later intermarried with Tibetan women and spoke Tibetan as their first language. The city's merchants catered to all kinds of tastes, importing even Australian butter and Scottish whisky. In the 1940s, according to <a href="Heinrich%20Harrer">Heinrich Harrer</a>:-
After the establishment of <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20China">Communist</a> Chinese <a href="China">People's Republic of China</a>, "(...) the People's Liberation Army (PLA) <a href="Invasion">invaded</a> the country in 1950. In <a href="Tibetan%20Uprising%20Day">March 1959, an uprising</a> centered on the <a href="Capital%20city">capital</a>, Lhasa, prompted a massive crackdown, during which the <a href="14th%20Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso (b. 1935)</a>, fled into exile." Such markets and consumerism came to an abrupt end after the arrival of Chinese government troops and administrative cadres in 1950. Food rations and poorly stocked government stores replaced the old markets, until the 1990s when commerce in international wares once more returned to Lhasa, and arcades and malls with a cornucopia of goods sprang up.
Of the 22 parks ("lingka"s) which surrounded the city of Lhasa, most of them over half a mile in length, where the people of Lhasa were accustomed to picnic, only three survive today: the <a href="Norbulingka">Norbulingka</a>, Dalai Lama's Summer Palace, constructed by the <a href="7th%20Dalai%20Lama">7th Dalai Lama</a>; a small part of the Shugtri Lingka, and the <a href="Lukhang">Lukhang</a>. Dormitory blocks, offices and army barracks are built over the rest.
The <a href="Guan%20Yu">Guāndì miào (關帝廟)</a> or <a href="Epic%20of%20King%20Gesar">Gesar</a> Lhakhang temple was erected by the Amban in 1792 atop Mount Bamare south of the Potala to celebrate the defeat of an invading <a href="Gurkha">Gurkha</a> army.
The main gate to the city of Lhasa used to run through the large Pargo Kaling <a href="chorten">chorten</a> and contained holy relics of the Buddha Mindukpa.
Between 1987 and 1989, Lhasa experienced major demonstrations, led by monks and nuns, against the Chinese Government. After <a href="Deng%20Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a>'s southern tour in 1992, Lhasa was mandated by the government to undergo economic liberalization. All government employees, their families and students were forbidden from practicing their religion, while monks and nuns were not allowed to enter government offices and the <a href="Tibet%20University">Tibet University</a> campus. Subsequent to the introduction of the economic development policies, the influx of migrants has dramatically altered the city's ethnic mix in Lhasa.
In 2000 the urbanised area covered , with a population of around 170,000. Official statistics of the metropolitan area report that 70 percent are Tibetan, 24.3 are Han, and the remaining 2.7 Hui, though outside observers suspect that non-Tibetans account for some 50–70 percent. Among the Han immigrants, Lhasa is known as 'Little Sichuan'.
Geography.
Lhasa has an elevation of about and lies in the centre of the Tibetan Plateau with the surrounding mountains rising to . The air only contains 68 percent of the oxygen compared to sea level. The <a href="Lhasa%20River">Lhasa River</a>, also Kyi River or Kyi Chu, a tributary of the <a href="Yarlung%20Zangbo%20River">Yarlung Zangbo River</a> (Brahmaputra River), runs through the southern part of the city. This river, known to local Tibetans as the "merry blue waves", flows through the snow-covered peaks and gullies of the <a href="Nyainq%C3%AAntanglha">Nyainqêntanglha</a> mountains, extending , and emptying into the Yarlung Zangbo River at <a href="Q%C3%BCx%C3%BC%20County">Qüxü</a>, forms an area of great scenic beauty. The marshlands, mostly uninhabited, are to the north. Ingress and egress roads run east and west, while to the north, the road infrastructure is less developed.
Administration.
Chengguan District is located on the middle reaches of the <a href="Lhasa%20River">Lhasa River</a>, a tributary of the <a href="Brahmaputra%20River">Brahmaputra River</a>, with land that rises to the north and south of the river.
It is from east to west and from north to south.
Chengguan District is bordered by <a href="Doilungd%C3%AAq%C3%AAn%20District">Doilungdêqên District</a> to the west, <a href="Dagz%C3%AA%20County">Dagzê County</a> to the east and <a href="Lh%C3%BCnzhub%20County">Lhünzhub County</a> to the north. 
<a href="Gonggar%20County">Gonggar County</a> of Lhoka (Shannan) Prefecture lies to the south.
Chengguan District has an elevation of and covers .
The urban built-up area covers .
The average annual temperature of .
Annual precipitation is about , mostly falling between July and September.
The term "Chengguan District" is the administrative term for the inner urban area or the urban centre within a prefecture, in this case the Prefectural-city of Lhasa. Outside of the urban area much of Chengguan District is mainly mountainous with a near nonexistent rural population.
Chengguan District is at the same administrative level as a county.
Chengguan District of Lhasa was established on 23 April 1961. 
It currently has 12 fully urban subdistricts.
Climate.
Owing to its very high elevation, Lhasa has a borderline <a href="cool%20semi-arid%20climate">cool semi-arid</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a>: "BSk")/monsoon-influenced <a href="continental%20climate">continental climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a>: "Dwb") using the isotherm with frosty winters and mild summers, yet the valley location protects the city from intense cold or heat and strong winds. Monthly possible sunshine ranges from 53 percent in July to 84 percent in November, and the city receives nearly 3,000 hours of sunlight annually. It is thus sometimes called the "sunlit city" by Tibetans. The coldest month is January with an average temperature of and the warmest month is June with a daily average of , though nights have generally been warmer in July. The annual mean temperature is , with extreme temperatures ranging from . Lhasa has an annual precipitation of with rain falling mainly in July, August and September. The driest month is December at and the wettest month is August, at . Summer is widely regarded the "best" of the year as rains come mostly at night and Lhasa is still sunny during the daytime.
Demographics.
Demographics in the past.
The 11th edition of "<a href="Encyclop%C3%A6dia%20Britannica%20Eleventh%20Edition">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>" published between 1910 and 1911 noted the total population of Lhasa, including the lamas in the city and vicinity was about 30,000; a census in 1854 made the figure 42,000, but it is known to have greatly decreased since. "Britannica" noted that within Lhasa, there were about a total of 1,500 resident Tibetan laymen and about 5,500 Tibetan women. The permanent population also included Chinese families (about 2,000). The city's residents included traders from Nepal and Ladak (about 800), and a few from Bhutan, Mongolia and other places. The "Britannica" noted with interest that the Chinese had a crowded burial-ground at Lhasa, tended carefully after their manner and that the Nepalese supplied mechanics and metal-workers at that time.
In the first half of the 20th century, several <a href="Western%20culture">Western</a> explorers made celebrated journeys to the city, including <a href="William%20Montgomery%20McGovern">William Montgomery McGovern</a>, <a href="Francis%20Younghusband">Francis Younghusband</a>, <a href="Alexandra%20David-N%C3%A9el">Alexandra David-Néel</a>, and <a href="Heinrich%20Harrer">Heinrich Harrer</a>. Lhasa was the centre of Tibetan Buddhism as nearly half of its population were <a href="monk">monk</a>s, Though this figure may include monks from surrounding monasteries who travelled to Lhasa for various celebrations and were not ordinarily resident there.
The majority of the pre-1950 Chinese population of Lhasa were merchants and officials. In the Lubu section of Lhasa, the inhabitants were descendants of Chinese vegetable farmers, some of whom married Tibetan wives. They came to Lhasa in the 1840s–1860s after a Chinese official was appointed to the position of <a href="Amban">Amban</a>.
According to one writer, the population of the city was about 10,000, with some 10,000 monks at Drepung and Sera monasteries in 1959. Hugh Richardson, on the other hand, puts the population of Lhasa in 1952, at "some 25,000–30,000—about 45,000–50,000 if the population of the great monasteries on its outskirts be included."
Contemporary demographics.
The total population of Lhasa Prefecture-level City is 521,500 (including known migrant population but excluding military garrisons). Of this, 257,400 are in the urban area (including a migrant population of 100,700), while 264,100 are outside. Nearly half of Lhasa Prefecture-level City's population lives in Chengguan District, which is the administrative division that contains the urban area of Lhasa (i.e. the actual city).
The urban area is populated by ethnic Tibetans, Han, Hui and other ethnic groups. The 2000 official census gave a total population of 223,001, of which 171,719 lived in the areas administered by city street offices and city neighborhood committees. 
133,603 had urban registrations and 86,395 had rural registrations, based on their place of origin.
The census was taken in November, when many of the ethnic Han workers in seasonal industries such as construction would have been away from Tibet, and did not count the military.
A 2011 book estimated that up to two-thirds of the city's residents are non-Tibetan, although the government states that Chengguan District as a whole is still 63% ethnic Tibetan. , half of Tibet's Han population resided in Chengguan District of Lhasa, where <a href="Bilingual%20education">bilingual</a> or wholly Chinese teaching was common in the schools.
Economy.
Competitive industry together with feature economy play key roles in the development of Lhasa. With the view to maintaining a balance between population growth and the environment, tourism and service industries are emphasised as growth engines for the future.
Many of Lhasa's rural residents practice traditional agriculture and <a href="animal%20husbandry">animal husbandry</a>. Lhasa is also the traditional hub of the Tibetan trading network. For many years, chemical and car making plants operated in the area and this resulted in significant pollution, a factor which has changed in recent years. <a href="Copper">Copper</a>, <a href="lead">lead</a> and <a href="zinc">zinc</a> are mined nearby and there is ongoing experimentation regarding new methods of mineral mining and geothermal heat extraction.
Agriculture and animal husbandry in Lhasa are considered to be of a high standard. People mainly plant <a href="highland%20barley">highland barley</a> and winter <a href="wheat">wheat</a>. The resources of water conservancy, <a href="geothermal%20heating">geothermal heating</a>, <a href="solar%20energy">solar energy</a> and various mines are abundant. There is widespread electricity together with the use of both <a href="machinery">machinery</a> and traditional methods in the production of such things as <a href="textile">textile</a>s, <a href="leather">leather</a>s, plastics, matches and <a href="embroidery">embroidery</a>. The production of national handicrafts has made great progress.
With the growth of tourism and service sectors, the sunset industries which cause serious pollution are expected to fade in the hope of building a healthy ecological system. Environmental problems such as <a href="soil%20erosion">soil erosion</a>, <a href="Soil%20acidification">acidification</a>, and loss of <a href="vegetation">vegetation</a> are being addressed. The tourism industry now brings significant business to the region, building on the attractiveness of the Potala Palace, the <a href="Jokang">Jokang</a>, the <a href="Norbulingka">Norbulingka</a> Summer Palace and surrounding large monasteries as well the spectacular <a href="Himalaya">Himalaya</a>n landscape together with the many wild plants and animals native to the high altitudes of <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a>. Tourism to Tibet dropped sharply following the crackdown on protests in 2008, but as early as 2009, the industry was recovering. Chinese authorities plan an ambitious growth of tourism in the region aiming at 10 million visitors by 2020; these visitors are expected to be domestic. With renovation around historic sites, such as the Potala Palace, <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> has expressed "concerns about the deterioration of Lhasa's traditional cityscape."
Lhasa contains several hotels. <a href="Lhasa%20Hotel">Lhasa Hotel</a> is a 4-star hotel located northeast of Norbulingka in the western suburbs of the city. Completed in September 1985, it is the flagship of CITS's installations in Tibet. It accommodates about 1000 guests and visitors to Lhasa. There are over 450 rooms (suites) in the hotel, and all are equipped with <a href="air%20conditioning">air conditioning</a>, <a href="mini-bar">mini-bar</a> and other basic facilities. Some of the rooms are decorated in traditional Tibetan style. The hotel was operated by Holiday Inn from 1986 to 1997 and is the subject of a book, "<a href="The%20Hotel%20on%20the%20Roof%20of%20the%20World">The Hotel on the Roof of the World</a>". Another hotel of note is the historical <a href="Banak%20Sh%C3%B6l%20Hotel">Banak Shöl Hotel</a>, located at 8 Beijing Road in the city. It is known for its distinctive wooden <a href="veranda">veranda</a>s. The Nam-tso Restaurant is located in the vicinity of the hotel and is frequented especially by Chinese tourists visiting Lhasa.
Lhasa contains several businesses of note. <a href="Lhasa%20Carpet%20Factory">Lhasa Carpet Factory</a>, a <a href="factory">factory</a> south of Yanhe Dong Lu near the <a href="Tibet%20University">Tibet University</a>, produces traditional <a href="Tibetan%20rug">Tibetan rug</a>s that are exported worldwide. It is a modern factory, the largest manufacturer of rugs throughout Tibet, employing some 300 workers. Traditionally Tibetan women were the weavers, and men the spinners, but both work on the rugs today.
The <a href="Lhasa%20Brewery%20Company">Lhasa Brewery Company</a> was established in 1988 on the northern outskirts of Lhasa, south of <a href="Sera%20Monastery">Sera Monastery</a> and is the highest commercial brewery in the world at and accounts for 85 percent of contemporary beer production in Tibet. The brewery, consisting of five-story buildings, cost an estimated US$20–25 million, and by 1994, production had reached 30,000 bottles per day, employing some 200 workers by this time. Since 2000, the <a href="Carlsberg%20Group">Carlsberg group</a> has increased its stronghold in the Chinese market and has become increasingly influential in the country with investment and expertise. Carlsberg invested in the Lhasa Brewery in recent years and has drastically improved the brewing facility and working conditions, renovating and expanding the building to what now covers 62,240 square metres (15.3 acres).
Architecture and cityscape.
Lhasa has many sites of historic interest, including the <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a>, <a href="Jokhang%20Temple">Jokhang Temple</a>, <a href="Sera%20Monastery">Sera Monastery</a> and <a href="Norbulingka">Norbulingka</a>. The Potala Palace, Jokhang Temple and the Norbulingka are UNESCO world heritage sites. However, many important sites were damaged or destroyed mostly, but not solely, during China's <a href="Cultural%20Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> of the 1960s. Many have been restored since the 1980s.
The <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a>, named after Mount Potala, the abode of <a href="Chenresig">Chenresig</a> or <a href="Avalokitesvara">Avalokitesvara</a>, was the chief residence of the <a href="Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a>. After the <a href="14th%20Dalai%20Lama">14th Dalai Lama</a> fled to <a href="India">India</a> during the <a href="1959%20Tibetan%20uprising">1959 Tibetan uprising</a>, the government converted the palace into a museum. The site was used as a <a href="meditation">meditation</a> retreat by King <a href="Songtsen%20Gampo">Songtsen Gampo</a>, who in 637 built the first palace there in order to greet his bride <a href="Princess%20Wen%20Cheng">Princess Wen Cheng</a> of the <a href="Tang%20dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> of China. <a href="Lozang%20Gyatso%2C%205th%20Dalai%20Lama">Lozang Gyatso</a>, the Great Fifth Dalai Lama, started the construction of the Potala Palace in 1645 after one of his spiritual advisers, Konchog Chophel (d. 1646), pointed out that the site was ideal as a seat of government, situated as it is between <a href="Drepung">Drepung</a> and <a href="Sera%20Monastery">Sera</a> monasteries and the old city of Lhasa. The palace underwent restoration works between 1989 and 1994, costing RMB55 million (US$6.875 million) and was inscribed to the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20List">World Heritage List</a> in 1994.
The <a href="Lhasa%20Zhol%20Pillar">Lhasa Zhol Pillar</a>, below the Potala, dates as far back as circa 764 CE. and is inscribed with what may be the oldest known example of Tibetan writing. The pillar contains dedications to a famous Tibetan general and gives an account of his services to the king including campaigns against China which culminated in the brief capture of the Chinese capital <a href="Chang%27an">Chang'an</a> (modern <a href="Xian">Xian</a>) in 763 CE during which the Tibetans temporarily installed as Emperor a relative of Princess Jincheng Gongzhu (Kim-sheng Kong co), the Chinese wife of <a href="Trisong%20Detsen">Trisong Detsen</a>'s father, <a href="Me%20Agtsom">Me Agtsom</a>.
<a href="Chokpori">Chokpori</a>, meaning 'Iron Mountain', is a <a href="sacred">sacred</a> <a href="hill">hill</a>, located south of the Potala. It is considered to be one of the four holy mountains of central Tibet and along with two other hills in Lhasa represent the "Three Protectors of Tibet.", Chokpori (<a href="Vajrapani">Vajrapani</a>), Pongwari (<a href="Manjushri">Manjushri</a>), and Marpori (<a href="Chenresig">Chenresig</a> or <a href="Avalokiteshvara">Avalokiteshvara</a>). It was the site of the most famous <a href="medical%20school">medical school</a> Tibet, known as the <a href="Mentsikhang">Mentsikhang</a>, which was founded in 1413. It was conceived of by <a href="Lobsang%20Gyatso">Lobsang Gyatso</a>, the "Great" 5th Dalai Lama, and completed by the Regent <a href="Sangye%20Gyatso">Sangye Gyatso</a> (Sangs-rgyas rgya-mtsho) shortly before 1697.
<a href="Lingkhor">Lingkhor</a> is a <a href="sacred">sacred</a> path, most commonly used to name the outer <a href="pilgrim">pilgrim</a> road in Lhasa matching its inner twin, Barkhor. The Lingkhor in Lhasa was long enclosing Old Lhasa, the Potala and <a href="Chokpori">Chokpori</a> hill. In former times it was crowded with men and women covering its length in <a href="prostration">prostration</a>s, <a href="beggar">beggar</a>s and <a href="pilgrim">pilgrim</a>s approaching the city for the first time. The road passed through willow-shaded parks where the Tibetans used to <a href="picnic">picnic</a> in summer and watch open air operas on festival days. New Lhasa has obliterated most of Lingkhor, but one stretch still remains west of Chokpori.
The <a href="Norbulingka">Norbulingka</a> palace and surrounding park is situated in the west side of Lhasa, a short distance to the southwest of Potala Palace and with an area of around , it is considered to be the largest man made garden in Tibet.
It was built from 1755. and served as the traditional summer residence of the successive <a href="Dalai%20Lama">Dalai Lama</a>s until the 14th's self-imposed exile. Norbulingka was declared a 'National Important Cultural Relic Unit", in 1988 by the State council. In 2001, the Central Committee of the Chinese Government in its 4th Tibet Session resolved to restore the complex to its original glory. The <a href="Sho%20Dun%20Festival">Sho Dun Festival</a> (popularly known as the "yogurt festival") is an annual festival held at Norbulingka during the seventh Tibetan month in the first seven days of the <a href="Full%20Moon">Full Moon</a> period, which corresponds to dates in July/August according to the <a href="Gregorian%20calendar">Gregorian calendar</a>.
The <a href="Barkhor">Barkhor</a> is an area of narrow streets and a public square in the old part of the city located around <a href="Jokhang%20Temple">Jokhang Temple</a> and was the most popular devotional circumambulation for pilgrims and locals. The walk was about one kilometre () long and encircled the entire <a href="Jokhang">Jokhang</a>, the former seat of the <a href="Nechung%20Oracle">State Oracle</a> in Lhasa called the <a href="Muru%20Nyingba%20Monastery">Muru Nyingba Monastery</a>, and a number of nobles' houses including <a href="Tromzikhang">Tromzikhang</a> and <a href="Jamkhang">Jamkhang</a>. There were four large incense burners ("sangkangs") in the four cardinal directions, with incense burning constantly, to please the gods protecting the Jokhang. Most of the old streets and buildings have been demolished in recent times and replaced with wider streets and new buildings. Some buildings in the Barkhor were damaged in the 2008 unrest.
The <a href="Jokhang">Jokhang</a> is located on Barkhor Square in the old town section of Lhasa. For most Tibetans it is the most sacred and important temple in Tibet. It is in some regards pan-sectarian, but is presently controlled by the <a href="Gelug">Gelug</a> school. Along with the <a href="Potala%20Palace">Potala Palace</a>, it is probably the most popular tourist attraction in Lhasa. It is part of the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a> "Historic Ensemble of the Potala Palace," and a spiritual centre of Lhasa. This temple has remained a key center of <a href="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> <a href="pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a> for centuries. The circumambulation route is known as the "kora" in Tibetan and is marked by four large stone incense burners placed at the corners of the temple complex. The Jokhang temple is a four-story construction, with roofs covered with <a href="gilded">gilded</a> <a href="bronze">bronze</a> tiles. The <a href="architecture">architectural</a> style is based on the Indian <a href="vihara">vihara</a> design, and was later extended resulting in a blend of <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a>ese and <a href="Tang%20dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> styles. It possesses the statues of <a href="Chenresig">Chenresig</a>, <a href="Padmasambhava">Padmasambhava</a> and King <a href="Songtsen%20Gampo">Songtsan Gampo</a> and his two foreign brides, Princess <a href="Wen%20Cheng">Wen Cheng</a> (niece of <a href="Emperor%20Taizong%20of%20Tang">Emperor Taizong of Tang</a>) and Princess <a href="Bhrikuti">Bhrikuti</a> of <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a> and other important items.
<a href="Ramoche%20Temple">Ramoche Temple</a> is considered the most important temple in Lhasa after the Jokhang Temple. Situated in the northwest of the city, it is east of the Potala and north of the Jokhang, covering a total area of 4,000 square meters (almost one acre). The temple was gutted and partially destroyed in the 1960s and its famous bronze statue disappeared. In 1983 the lower part of it was said to have been found in a Lhasa rubbish tip, and the upper half in Beijing. They have now been joined and the statue is housed in the Ramoche Temple, which was partially restored in 1986, and still showed severe damage in 1993. Following the major restoration of 1986, the main building in the temple now has three stories.
The <a href="Tibet%20Museum%20%28Lhasa%29">Tibet Museum</a> in Lhasa is the official museum of the Tibet Autonomous Region and was inaugurated on October 5, 1999. It is the first large, modern museum in the Tibet Autonomous Region and has a permanent collection of around 1000 artefacts, from examples of Tibetan art to architectural design throughout history such as Tibetan doors and construction beams. It is located in an L-shaped building west of the Potala Palace on the corner of <a href="Norbulingkha%20Road">Norbulingkha Road</a>. The museum is organized into three main sections: a main exhibition hall, a folk cultural garden and administrative offices.
The <a href="Monument%20to%20the%20Peaceful%20Liberation%20of%20Tibet">Monument to the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet</a> was unveiled in the Potala Square in May 2002 to celebrate the 51st anniversary of the <a href="Seventeen%20Point%20Agreement%20for%20the%20Peaceful%20Liberation%20of%20Tibet">Seventeen Point Agreement for the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet</a>, and the work in the development of the autonomous region since then. The 37-metre-high concrete monument is shaped as an abstract Mount Everest and its name is engraved with the calligraphy of former CCP general secretary and PRC president <a href="Jiang%20Zemin">Jiang Zemin</a>, while an inscription describes the socioeconomic development experienced in Tibet in the past fifty years.
There are four mosques in and around Lhasa. The earliest mosque, called "Khache Lingka", dates to 1650 and is located west of the city, and consists of two compounds. The <a href="Lhasa%20Great%20Mosque">Lhasa Great Mosque</a> is the most prominent and built by the early 1700s. The Dokdé Mosque, north of Lhasa, has an adjacent cemetery and is dated to 1716. The fourth mosque, commonly known as "Small Mosque" (but also Barkor or Rapsel Alley Mosque) was built in the early 1900s. 
Culture.
Music and dance.
There are some night spots that feature <a href="cabaret">cabaret</a> acts in which performers sing in <a href="Chinese%20language">Chinese</a>, <a href="Standard%20Tibetan">Tibetan</a>, and <a href="English%20language">English</a>. Dancers wear traditional Tibetan costume with long flowing cloth extending from their arms. There are a number of small bars that feature live music, although they typically have limited drink menus and cater mostly to foreign tourists.
Education.
Tibet University.
<a href="Tibet%20University">Tibet University</a> (<a href="Standard%20Tibetan">Tibetan</a>: བོད་ལྗོངས་སློབ་གྲྭ་ཆེན་མོ་) is the main <a href="university">university</a> of <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a>. Its campus is in Chengguan District, Lhasa, east of the city-centre. A forerunner was created in 1952 and the university was officially established in 1985, funded by the <a href="Government%20of%20the%20People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">Chinese government</a>. About 8000 students are enrolled at the university.
Tibet University is a comprehensive university with the highest academic level in <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a>. It is a member of the prestigious <a href="Project%20211">Project 211</a>, and is sponsored under the <a href="Double%20First%20Class%20University%20Plan">Double First Class Disciplines</a> initiative.
Transport.
Rail.
Lhasa has been served by rail since 2006, when the <a href="Qinghai%E2%80%93Tibet%20Railway">Qinghai–Tibet Railway</a> opened for passenger operations. Reaching an elevation of 5,072 metres above sea level, the Qinghai-Tibet railway is the world's highest railway by elevation. It connects Lhasa with <a href="Xining">Xining</a>, the capital of <a href="Qinghai%20Province">Qinghai Province</a>, some away, and ultimately links Lhasa with other major cities with China's extensive railway network. Five trains arrive at and depart from <a href="Lhasa%20railway%20station">Lhasa railway station</a> each day. Train number Z21 takes 40 hours and 53 minutes from <a href="Beijing%20West%20railway%20station">Beijing West</a>, arriving in Lhasa at 13:03 every day. Train Z22 from Lhasa to Beijing West departs at 15:30 and arrives in Beijing at 08:20 on the third day, taking 40 hours, 50 minutes. Trains also arrive in Lhasa from <a href="Chengdu">Chengdu</a>, <a href="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>, <a href="Lanzhou">Lanzhou</a>, Xining, <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> and other cities. To counter the problem of altitude differences giving passengers <a href="altitude%20sickness">altitude sickness</a>, extra oxygen is pumped in through the ventilation system and available directly on each berth with close open control by a flap for convenience of passenger, and personal oxygen masks are available on request. Within the soft sleeper cabins there are 64 seats per train, which have an electrical plug for electronics. Lhasa is also <a href="Lhasa%E2%80%93Xigaz%C3%AA%20Railway">connected</a> to the second largest city in Tibet, <a href="Shigatse">Xigazê</a>, by rail service, since 2014. A third railway, the <a href="Sichuan-Tibet%20Railway">Sichuan-Tibet Railway</a>, which links Lhasa with <a href="Nyingchi%20County">Nyingchi County</a> and into the interior ultimately terminating in <a href="Chengdu">Chengdu</a>, began construction in June 2015.
For onward rail travel in <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>, the closest major station in India is <a href="New%20Jalpaiguri">New Jalpaiguri</a>, <a href="Siliguri">Siliguri</a> in <a href="West%20Bengal">West Bengal</a>. However, extension of the Indian railway system to <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a> will make it easier for onward connections through the <a href="South%20Asian">South Asian</a> railway network. There are preliminary plans to link Lhasa by rail with Kathmandu.
As per a Chinese Tibetan spokesperson, extension of this rail line to Kathmandu with tunnelling under <a href="Mount%20Everest">Mount Everest</a> was expected to be completed by 2020.
Air.
<a href="Lhasa%20Gonggar%20Airport">Lhasa Gonggar Airport</a> (IATA: LXA), built in 1965, is the aviation hub of Tibet. It is located south of the city proper. It takes around half an hour to get there by car via the <a href="Lhasa%20Airport%20Expressway">Lhasa Airport Expressway</a>; prior to the completion of the expressway in 2011, the trip to the airport took over an hour. , there are daily flights serving major Chinese cities including Beijing, Chengdu, Guangzhou, and Shanghai, and there are also occasional scheduled services to <a href="Kathmandu">Kathmandu</a> in Nepal. Lhasa Airport is the hub of <a href="Tibet%20Airlines">Tibet Airlines</a>, which offers regional services to other destinations in Tibet such as <a href="Nyingchi">Nyingchi</a>, <a href="Ngari%20Prefecture">Ngari Prefecture</a>, <a href="Shigatse">Shigatse</a>, and <a href="Qamdo">Qamdo</a>.
Road.
The <a href="Qinghai%E2%80%93Tibet%20Highway">Qinghai–Tibet Highway</a> (part of G109) runs northeast toward Xining and eventually to <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a> and is the most-used road in Tibet. The <a href="Sichuan%E2%80%93Tibet%20Highway">Sichuan–Tibet Highway</a> (part of G318) runs east towards <a href="Chengdu">Chengdu</a> and eventually to <a href="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>. G318 also runs west to <a href="Zhangmu">Zhangmu</a> on the Nepal border. The <a href="China%20National%20Highway%20219">Xinjiang-Tibet Highway</a> (G219) runs north from Lhasa to <a href="Kargilik%20Town">Yecheng</a>, and then to <a href="Xinjiang">Xinjiang</a>. This road is rarely used due to the lack of amenities and petrol stations. A new , four-lane highway between Lhasa and the Gonggar Airport was built by the Transportation Department of Tibet at a cost of <a href="Renminbi">RMB</a> 1.5 billion. This road is part of <a href="China%20National%20Highway%20318">National Highway 318</a> and starts from the <a href="Lhasa%20railway%20station">Lhasa railway station</a>, passes through <a href="Caina%20Township">Caina Township</a> in <a href="Qushui%20County">Qushui County</a>, terminating between the north entrance of the <a href="Gala%20Mountain%20Tunnel">Gala Mountain Tunnel</a> and the south bridgehead of the Lhasa River Bridge, and en route goes over the first overpass of Lhasa at Liuwu Overpass.
Maritime.
The closest seaports are <a href="Kolkata">Kolkata</a> and <a href="Haldia">Haldia</a> in <a href="West%20Bengal">West Bengal</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. The <a href="Nathu%20La">Nathu La</a> pass offers Chinese companies access to the port of Kolkata (Calcutta), situated about from Lhasa, for trans-shipments to and from Tibet.
Sports.
The <a href="Lhasa%20Stadium">Lhasa Stadium</a>, which has a capacity of 20,000, is located in Lhasa. It is used mostly for football matches.
